de.uni.bamberg.wiai.minf.forflow.datagenerator.controller.datageneration.filltype
Class Interval

java.lang.Object
  de.uni.bamberg.wiai.minf.forflow.datagenerator.controller.datageneration.filltype.Interval
All Implemented Interfaces:
FillBehaviour, ObservableFillBehaviour
public class Interval
extends java.lang.Object
implements FillBehaviour

Interval implements FillBehaviour

Of course, it should be possible to define an interval as a filling behaviour for an given attribute. An interval is a set of numbers with the property that any number that lies between two numbers in the set is also included into it. For example, the set of all numbers x satisfying 0 ≤ x ≤ 20 is an interval which contains 0 and 20, as well as all numbers between them.

An interval can be described as:
  • integer

Endpoints (upper & lower bound)
The interval of numbers between x and y, including x and y is denoted [x, y]. The two numbers are called the endpoints of the interval. To distinguish between between the upper and lower endpoint, we call them upper bound and lower bound.

Notation of intervals
To indicate that one of the endpoints is to be excluded from the set, we use the following notation: 

 
 ]x, y[ = {z | x < z < y}
 [x, y[ = {z | x ≤ z < y}
 ]x, y] = {z | x < z ≤ y}
 [x, y] = {z | x ≤ z ≤ y}

Observable
Notice, the class implements FillBehaviour interface. It makes this kind of strategy observable. Observable means in this context, whenever an observer registers to or un-registers from this class, the subject itself notifies the UI to register this class in a specific list of generators.

Since:
Apr/29/09
Version:

Author:
Michael Munz

Constructor Detail

Interval

public Interval()
default constructor set the interval to integer values.

Method Detail

setInterval

public boolean setInterval(java.lang.String interval)
sets the interval of a given attribute (facet). The interval is verified and the success of this process is returned to the invoker method as feedback.

Example:

Suppose you wanna have an interval between one and fourteen, inclusive endpoints. All valid intervals to achieve this are:

]a, b[ → ]0, 15[
[a, b[ → [1, 15[
]a, b] → ]0, 14]
[a, b] → [1, 14]

Parameters:
interval - the interval is given as a string, 'cos we need the brackets to indicate the case.
Returns:
true, if a valid interval has been parsed, otherwise false

getEndpointsOfInterval

public final int[] getEndpointsOfInterval()
returns the current interval for an attribute as an array of length two. You can access the endpoints as follows:
int[0] = lowerBound (inclusive) int[1] = upperBound (inclusive)

Returns:
array of length two containing upper & lower endpoints.

N = Σn_i
See Also:
calculateN(int, int)

getN

public final int getN()
Description copied from interface: FillBehaviour
each filling behaviour whether it is via a value file, an interval or by editor each of them has a range of values. This range is referred to as N. N is the total number of possible or available values to use for generation.

Example
Imagine having a value file called names.txt. The file has in total about 300 names, so as a result N = 300; Each of those values n = 1, ..., N gets a probability value later when it comes to probability distributions. A particular probability density function is laid over the values.

Probability density function
As an example we assume the Uniform probability distribution is used. The probability density function is for all values constant. In other words, each values is equal likely. P(X=x) = 1/N. 
 f(x)
  |
  |
  |------------ (1/N)
  |
  |
  |___________|______
              N    values

Specified by:
getN in interface FillBehaviour
Returns:
number of values N = Σn_i for this filling behaviour.

getValueAt

public final java.lang.String getValueAt(int n)
Description copied from interface: FillBehaviour
this method has the job of retrieving the value at the specified index. Most fill behaviour strategies are based on value files. These files have a specific amount of possible values from i = 1, ..., n where i is the index. When the process of generating test data is activated, to each facet values of the fill behaviour are used. To get values in the range of the value file, this method is needed. By the way, only the strategies itselves have access to value files.

Specified by:
getValueAt in interface FillBehaviour
Parameters:
n - the index specifies the value at position n to retrieve.
Returns:
the value at position n or null

a meaningful name
